content.text: Measure the length \(l\), width \(w\) and height \(h\) of block A. Record your values in centimetres to the nearest millimetre
Calculate the volume \(V_{\mathrm{A}}\) of block A. Use your measurements from (a)(i) and the equation \(V_{\mathrm{A}} = l \times w \times h\)
Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in measuring the dimensions of the block
Describe how the accuracy of these measurements can be improved
You are **not** required to do this improved investigation
suggestion
improvement
Measure the mass \(m_{\mathrm{A}}\) of block A. Use the top-pan balance

Calculate a value \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}}\) for the density of the modelling clay. Use your results from **(a)**(ii) and **(c)** and the equation \(\rho_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{m_{\mathrm{A}}}{V_{\mathrm{A}}}\). Include the unit for the density
Method 2
Measure the weight \(W_{\mathrm{B}}\) of block B, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Pour approximately \(60 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder
Measure and record the actual volume \(V_{1}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder
Remove the loop of thread from the force meter and lower block B carefully into the water in the measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 1.3
Measure and record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the measuring cylinder
Draw an arrow on Fig. 1.4 to show the correct line of sight to obtain the value for the volume of water in the measuring cylinder
Calculate another value \(\rho_{\mathrm{B}}\) for the density of modelling clay. Use your readings from **(e)** and \(\frac{W_{\mathrm{B}} \times k}{(V_{2} - V_{1})}\), where \(k = 100 \text{g/N}\)
In this experiment, you will determine the density of modelling clay by two methods
Refer to Fig. 1.1
**Method 1**
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Use the graduations on the beaker as a guide. Place the thermometer in the water
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-watch
Record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\)
Remove the thermometer from the beaker and pour out the water
Repeat (a), using only \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water
Add units to the column headings in Table 2.1

content.text: Write a conclusion stating how the volume of hot water affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to your results
Using your values for \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) for the first \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Using your values for \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) for the last \(90 \text{s}\) of the experiment. Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
A student states that it is important to start the two experiments in (a) and (b) with water at the same initial temperature
Explain whether your values for \(x_{1}\) and \(x_{2}\) support this statement
Another student repeats the experiment
State one variable, other than initial water temperature, that she should control to obtain readings that are as close as possible to those in Table 2.1
In this experiment, you will investigate how the volume of water affects the rate at which hot water in a beaker cools
Refer to Fig. 2.1

parts.label: (i)

content.text: Measure the height \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\) of the illuminated object. Fig. 3.1 shows the height to measure on the illuminated object provided

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
Place the screen near the lens
Switch on the lamp
Move the screen until a focused image of the illuminated object is seen on the screen
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the height \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) of the image on the screen
Repeat the procedure for \(u = 25.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}, 35.0 \text{cm}\) and \(40.0 \text{cm}\)
Switch off the lamp
Describe a technique for obtaining an image that is as sharp as possible
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 3.1
For each distance \(u\), calculate, and record in Table 3.1, a value \(W.\) Use your results from **(a)** and the equation \(W = \frac{h_0}{h_1}.\)
Plot a graph of \(u / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(W\) (x-axis). You do **not** need to start your axes at the origin \((0, 0)\). Draw the best-fit line
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the line. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The focal length \(f\) of the lens is numerically equal to the gradient \(G\)
Record a value of \(f\) for this experiment
A student decides to continue the experiment using larger values of \(u\)
Explain why this produces less accurate values for \(W\)
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens
Refer to Fig. 3.1
illuminated object
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter of a wire and the electrical resistance of the wire
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects the resistance of the wire
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire
You are **not** required to do this experiment
The apparatus available includes wires of different known diameters
In your plan:
· list any additional apparatus needed
· complete Fig. 4.1 to show a circuit suitable for measuring the resistance of a wire
· explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined
· state the key variables to keep constant
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
